questions.question: How can you get a vaccine for yourself or someone you care about?
questions.answer:
Nearly all COVID vaccine distributors require you to schedule an appointment in advance of getting a vaccine. When you or someone you care about becomes eligible, you can schedule an appointment online or over the phone. There are two primary ways you can find a vaccine appointment:

1. [VaccineFinder](https://vaccinefinder.org/search/) is a federally supported website managed in partnership with the CDC. It allows individuals to see where vaccines are in stock near their selected zip code, and it provides the phone number, website link, and directions to these sites. VaccineFinder does not show every vaccine location in every state; it generally focuses on federally enrolled vaccine distributors such as pharmacies. In most cases, VaccineFinder is easier to navigate than websites run by state governments.

2. [Your state department of health website](https://www.cdc.gov/publichealthgateway/healthdirectories/healthdepartments.html) will provide more comprehensive information about where and how you can get vaccinated in your state. These websites often highlight state-run vaccination sites, such as converted stadiums or convention centers. They also will likely provide more information on how to get vaccinated at locally-run sites, such as hospitals.

It is important to note that while vaccines remain in high demand, securing a vaccine appointment may require persistence and effort. New vaccine appointments are added daily, so you should frequently check back online or call vaccination sites to see if appointments have become available.

questions.question: When can children get the COVID vaccine?
questions.answer:
No COVID vaccine is currently approved for use on children ages 15 and younger. [Pfizer recently announced](https://www.pfizer.com/news/press-release/press-release-detail/pfizer-biontech-announce-positive-topline-results-pivotal) positive results from its vaccine trial in children aged 12 to 15, which showed 100 percent efficacy against severe illness and death. It has applied to the FDA for emergency use authorization in the hopes that the age group will be able to get vaccinated prior to the fall school year. Moderna is also testing its vaccine in children, and should provide results soon.

In March 2021, Pfizer began a [trial for children 6 months to 11 years](https://www.pfizer.com/science/coronavirus/vaccine/additional-population-studies#gl-base:~:text=When%20can%20we%20expect%20results%20from%20this%20study%3F%20When%20will%20children%20be%20able%20to%20receive%20the%20vaccine%3F). We should expect results in the second half of 2021; if positive, it is likely children under 12 will be able to get vaccinated by early 2022 [according to Dr. Fauci](https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/17/us-could-start-vaccinating-young-kids-in-early-2022-dr-fauci-says-.html#:~:text=Anthony%20Fauci%20said.,the%20first%20quarter%20of%202022.). 

Children are difficult to study in vaccine trials because their immune system continues to develop from infancy through teenage years and is different at different ages. This means it is difficult to lump all ages of children into one trial group.

questions.question: Are COVID vaccines safe?
questions.answer:
Approved COVID vaccines were developed in record time, but this does not mean that any safety protocols were bypassed. All vaccines have gone through rigorous testing to ensure their safety. Each vaccine must undergo clinical trials, with study participants followed for two months after completing a vaccination series to prove that the vaccine is safe and effective, according to the [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinichealthsystem.org/hometown-health/featured-topic/covid-19-vaccine-myths-debunked). After the Food and Drug Administration determines that a vaccine is safe, the Advisory Committee on Immunization carefully reviews all available data before making its recommendation to the CDC.

Even after a vaccine is in use, the CDC continues to monitor its safety. Health care providers, for instance, are required to report adverse vaccine reactions to a [national warning system](https://vaers.hhs.gov/about.html). Fortunately, of the first 1.9 million people to receive shots of Pfizer-BioNTech’s COVID vaccine, only 0.2% [experienced an adverse event](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/70/wr/mm7002e1.htm), such as fatique or headache, and very few reactions were serious.

Learn more about [how federal partners are ensuring the safety of COVID vaccines in the United States.](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety.html)

questions.question: What are the side effects of the vaccine?
questions.answer:
Not everyone experiences side effects, but if you do, it is generally a sign that your body is building protection. While side effects may get in the way of your daily activities, they typically go away in a few days. According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/expect/after.html), side effects may include: 

* **Pain and swelling on your arm** **where you received the shot**. This can be alleviated by applying a clean, cool, wet washcloth over the area, or by using or exercising your arm. 
* **Fever, chills, tiredness, and headache**. To reduce discomfort from fever, drink plenty of fluids and dress lightly. You may also want to talk to your doctor about taking an over-the-counter medicine, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen. 

You may want to contact your doctor or healthcare provider if: 

* The area around your shot becomes more red and tender after 24 hours.
* Your side effects last longer than a few days or you feel concerned.

questions.question: When will you be eligible to get the vaccine?
questions.answer: Individuals 16 years of age and older are now eligible for the COVID vaccine in the U.S.

questions.question: What should you do with your COVID vaccine card?
questions.answer:
Keeping your COVID vaccine card safe is important. The card is not a legal document but rather a personal record of your medical care. It will most likely be safest if you keep it with your passport or other important papers. As with other personal documents, you should protect your privacy and avoid identity theft by not posting copies or photos (such as a selfie) of your card online in a manner that permits it to be read by others.

* If you’re getting a two-shot vaccine, your vaccine card will note when you are due to get your second shot. It can also be important to have when you show up for your second appointment, especially at a walk-up clinic.
* You should take a picture of it, make hard copies, or produce a PDF or similar file by scanning it for your own records. Laminating the original card is not recommended, since it would make it difficult to add additional information to the card, such as your second dose confirmation.

questions.question: Is it safe to get a COVID vaccine if you are pregnant or breastfeeding?
questions.answer:
[Experts](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/pregnancy.html) believe COVID vaccines are unlikely to pose a specific risk for people who are pregnant, but current data is limited, as pregnant and breastfeeding people were not purposefully included in COVID vaccine trials. Because of this, the CDC recommends pregnant and breastfeeding individuals seek the advice of their doctor in order to make an informed decision about vaccination.

One good indicator of the safety of the vaccines is that a number of women became [pregnant during clinical trials](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1_wHIYX-tGkGBPwuax7N8BxZPR4PTTCDm/view) and went on to have normal pregnancies. There is also a lot of data on other vaccinations during pregnancy. In general, inactivated, or killed virus, vaccines are considered safe to use in pregnancy. For instance, every year, pregnant people get a new flu vaccine, which is a killed virus vaccine. This may provide guidance in how to think about COVID vaccine boosters should they become necessary. 

There's also [evidence that antibodies present in breast milk can be transferred](https://www.ajog.org/article/S0002-9378(21)00187-3/fulltext) for added protection to the baby.

questions.question: If you have already had and recovered from COVID, should you still get vaccinated?
questions.answer:
Yes, even those who have had COVID should get vaccinated from the disease, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html). While getting COVID may provide you with some natural immunity, it’s not clear how long this protection may last, says the [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/coronavirus/in-depth/coronavirus-vaccine/art-20484859#:~:text=Getting%20COVID%2D19%20might,COVID%2D19%20vaccine.). Some [studies](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(20)30764-7/fulltext) have found that reinfection is possible, but a vaccine could boost your immune response.

 If you recently had COVID or were treated for COVID with monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma, the CDC recommends that you wait 90 days before getting a vaccine.

questions.question: What can you do after you are fully vaccinated?
questions.answer:
According to the March 2021 [CDC guidance](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated-guidance.html), if you are fully vaccinated, you can gather indoors with other fully vaccinated people without a mask. You can also gather with one other household of low risk, unvaccinated people. This means that if you’ve received the vaccine, you could socialize with another fully vaccinated family, but should not gather in larger groups or with high risk individuals.  

However, it’s important to continue wearing a mask and practicing social distancing when you are in public. While there’s a growing amount of [evidence](https://academic.oup.com/cid/advance-article/doi/10.1093/cid/ciab229/6167855) that vaccines help reduce transmission, you should continue to take precautions, like wearing a mask and practicing social distancing, to protect those around you until enough people have received the vaccine. For now, the CDC also advises against travel. This means that grandparents could visit their low risk grandchildren if they live locally, but shouldn’t travel or meet with more than one other household at a time.

questions.question: Who pays for vaccination?
questions.answer: Under the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, a COVID vaccine must be free of charge to anyone who wants it. The federal government has purchased millions of vaccine shots and distributed them to providers. While providers may charge a fee for administering the vaccine, both private insurance and public programs must cover 100 percent of the fee, according to the [Kaiser Family Foundation](https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-covid-19/issue-brief/vaccine-coverage-pricing-and-reimbursement-in-the-u-s/). Uninsured patients also face no charges, as providers are reimbursed for administrative costs by the [Provider Relief Fund](https://www.hrsa.gov/coronavirus), which was established under the CARES Act.

questions.question: What are the ingredients of the vaccines?
questions.answer:
According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html), the three COVID vaccines currently available in the United States do not contain eggs, preservatives, or latex. For a full list of ingredients, please see each vaccine’s fact sheet:

* [Pfizer-BioNTech COVID vaccine](https://www.fda.gov/media/144414/download)
* [Moderna COVID vaccine](https://www.fda.gov/media/144638/download)
* [Johnson & Johnson/Janssen COVID vaccine](https://www.fda.gov/media/146305/download)

questions.question: What percentage of people need to be vaccinated to achieve herd immunity?
questions.answer: [Herd immunity](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#herd-immunity) is when a large enough portion of a community is immune to a virus so that the virus can no longer spread easily from person to person. At this time, experts do not know what percentage of people need to be vaccinated to achieve herd immunity to COVID. The [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html) and other experts continue to study the topic and will provide more information as it is available.

questions.question: Will vaccination for COVID cause you to test positive for COVID?
questions.answer:
Receiving a COVID vaccine will not cause you to test positive for COVID. The mRNA vaccines, like Pfizer and Moderna, give instructions for your cells to make a piece of the spike protein, not the entire viral genome. The vaccines simply do not have enough RNA or even the complete RNA sequence to give a positive signal in testing. Similarly, the Johnson & Johnson vaccine — which takes a piece of DNA from the COVID spike protein and combines it with an [adenovirus to carry instructions](https://www.covidactnow.org/covid-explained/roundup-current-vaccine-progress) to your immune system — cannot cause you to test positive for COVID.

If you receive a positive test result in the days or weeks after you have been vaccinated, it is likely because it takes time for the vaccines to work and protection is not 100 percent effective. Anyone who becomes infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus should isolate as recommended.

After vaccination, people may attempt to get a [serology, or antibody, test](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#serology-test) to see if the vaccine has “worked.” However, serology tests focus on a wide set of antibodies, and the vaccine stimulates your immune system to produce antibodies only against the spike protein. So, in order to determine if vaccination has stimulated antibody production, we would need a test that specifically looks for antibodies to the spike protein.

questions.question: Can undocumented immigrants get a free COVID vaccine without legal risk?
questions.answer:
Proof of citizenship, residence or immigration status [is not required to be vaccinated in the U.S.](https://www.dhs.gov/news/2021/02/01/dhs-statement-equal-access-covid-19-vaccines-and-vaccine-distribution-sites) Vaccine sites should not request your social security number, and you can’t be denied vaccination access if you do not provide this type of documentation.

In order to sign up for a vaccine, you will likely be asked demographic, occupational, or health information, as well as need to show some form of ID. This information is important data for public health purposes, and will not be used for immigration enforcement. 

As vaccine requirements vary state to state, it's important to visit [your state’s public health department website](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/php/hd-search/index.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fphp%2Fopen-america%2Fhd-search%2Findex.html) to check out local vaccine signup requirements.

questions.question: How effective is the Johnson and Johnson vaccine?
questions.answer:
[Editor's Note: On April 13, 2021 the CDC and FDA [recommended a pause](https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/s0413-JJ-vaccine.html) in the use of the Johnson & Johnson/Janssen COVID vaccine in the United States out of an abundance of caution after extremely rare cases of blood clots were reported. The CDC will convene a meeting of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices on April 14 to address this issue. We will continue to update this information as more data becomes available.]

The J & J vaccine is equally effective at preventing hospitalization and death from COVID as the other two FDA approved vaccines in the U.S., and nearly as effective against severe COVID cases. It’s easier to transport and store than the other vaccines, and it only requires one shot. 

Check out efficacy details in the table below. While the J & J vaccine efficacy against mild, symptomatic disease is lower than it is for the other two approved vaccines, it was tested after the rise of the B. 1.1.7 and B.1.351 variants, which are more transmissible. [Studies](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/pfizer-jab-may-not-be-as-potent-against-b-1-351-variant) suggest that if the mRNA vaccines (Pfizer and Moderna) were tested against these same variants, they may also have some decreased efficacy.

![All three vaccines are 100% effective against COVID hospitalization and death.](/images_cms/screenshot-2021-03-29-211221.jpg "Vaccine efficacy")

In the future, boosters against the variants or for waning immunity might also become available, making the differences in these trials less important in the long run.

Take away: The best vaccine is the one you can get soonest.

questions.question: Can you get COVID even after being vaccinated?
questions.answer:
It’s [possible](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/health-departments/breakthrough-cases.html). However, the risk of infection, and particularly of severe illness or death, is dramatically lower after vaccination. Cases of COVID that appear in fully vaccinated people, sometimes called “vaccine breakthrough cases” are expected, according to the CDC, as no vaccine currently on the market is 100 percent effective in preventing all infections.

As of April 13, 2021, more than 75 million people in the United States were fully vaccinated. During that time, there were 5,814 reported cases of COVID vaccine breakthrough. The CDC recognizes that this is most likely an undercount, since information is incomplete, but the overall picture is encouraging: “Vaccine breakthrough cases occur in only a small percentage of vaccinated persons.”

questions.question: Which locations does Covid Act Now have vaccine eligibility information for?
questions.answer:
We currently have vaccine eligibility information for every U.S. state, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the Northern Mariana Islands.

Identifying vaccine eligibility information takes time, since the information is not standardized and cannot be processed automatically by a computer. It thus needs to be collected manually. What’s more, eligibility varies not only from state to state, but also sometimes by county, and even by city. Finally, vaccine eligibility information often changes frequently as states, counties, or cities adjust their roll-out plans, and making sure this information is up to date is a manual process of regularly checking government websites and press releases. For all those reasons, we focus on tracking vaccine eligibility at the state-level.

questions.question: How does Covid Act Now get vaccine eligibility information, and how often is it updated?
questions.answer: Our team frequently reviews official state government sites and updates vaccine eligibility information on our site every Monday and Thursday. Please note that we are not a government or health care organization. We do not provide testing, vaccination, or other on-the-ground COVID services.

questions.question: How is the coronavirus transmitted?
questions.answer: Evidence suggests that COVID spreads mainly from person to person, primarily through respiratory droplets that are released when a person sneezes, coughs, or talks. These droplets are propelled through the air and can land in the noses and mouths of people, especially those in close proximity (six feet or less), according to the [Centers for Disease Control](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html) (CDC) and [World Health Organization](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/question-and-answers-hub/q-a-detail/q-a-how-is-covid-19-transmitted?gclid=Cj0KCQjwqrb7BRDlARIsACwGad6u8LD7qnGFt5oFPYI4ngBzLUHYz2-9DZ_b4fruyio4ekVFoQR7l7YaAsm3EALw_wcB) (WHO). [Research](https://www.pnas.org/content/117/26/14857) supported by the CDC also suggests that COVID may spread through aerosol, or airborne, [transmission](/glossary#transmission). This is similar to transmission by droplets except that the amounts of fluid are much smaller and can linger in the air for a much longer time and [infect](/glossary#infection) people further than six feet away.

questions.question: How long does the coronavirus live on surfaces?
questions.answer: The [virus](/glossary#virus) can live from several hours to several days on surfaces, depending on the type of material (cardboard, plastic, etc.). Even so, the CDC says that COVID is not transmitted easily through surfaces and spreads mainly from person-to-person. If you are concerned about surface contamination, you can find details on appropriate cleaning and sanitizing protocols from the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/pdf/Reopening_America_Guidance.pdf#:~:text=Coronaviruses%20on%20surfaces%20and%20objects,and%20dirt%20from%20surfaces.).

questions.question: Who is most at risk of getting COVID?
questions.answer: Anyone who has been [exposed](/glossary#exposed) to COVID is at risk of contracting the disease, and people of all ages have experienced hospitalization and death. Some people, however, are at greater risk. Elderly individuals, particularly those 85 or older, and people with certain underlying medical conditions are at [higher risk](/glossary#comorbidity) of serious illness, according to the CDC. (Read more about people at increased risk of contracting COVID at the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/index.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fneed-extra-precautions%2Fpeople-at-increased-risk.html).)

questions.question: Which racial and ethnic minorities are at higher risk of contracting COVID and becoming seriously ill?
questions.answer:
Data from the CDC shows that race and ethnicity, similar to age, are risk factors for COVID. The rates of COVID cases, hospitalizations and deaths among Blacks, Hispanic and Latino persons, and American Indians and Native Alaskans are much higher than for white people, according to the CDC’s calculation of [COVID-19 Hospitalization and Death by Race/Ethnicity](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/investigations-discovery/hospitalization-death-by-race-ethnicity.html) (updated November 30, 2020). The [APM Research Lab](https://www.apmresearchlab.org/covid/deaths-by-race) finds that death rates are more than three times higher for Black, Latino, and Indigenous people than for white people (updated November 12, 2020).

A number of social factors contribute to COVID risk for racial and ethnic minorities. For example, many minorities have higher rates of poverty and less access to health care. This puts them at greater risk of underlying medical conditions that result in more severe COVID cases. Racial and ethnic minorities are also more likely to be essential workers, live in crowded multi-generational housing, and have less financial resources to take off work when sick or provide for necessities while sheltering in place. Discrimination, including racism, contributes to these long-term social deficits and more immediately to inadequate health care access, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/health-equity/race-ethnicity.html).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of COVID?
questions.answer: Symptoms of COVID vary widely between different people. The most common symptoms include fatigue, cough and fever. Loss of smell or taste is also a frequent, early symptom. Other symptoms that people with COVID may experience include shortness of breath, muscle or body ache, sore throat, chills, congestion, headache, stomach pain (including nausea and diarrhea), pink eye (conjunctivitis) and chest pain. COVID symptoms generally appear two to 14 days after exposure. For more information on symptoms and when to seek medical help, go to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html).

questions.question: How common is it to have COVID but not have any symptoms?
questions.answer: Many individuals infected with COVID are [asymptomatic](/glossary#asymptomatic) (that is, they do not have symptoms of the virus). When people do not know that they are ill, they do not take precautions. In much the same way, people who are “[presymptomatic](/glossary#presymptomatic-spread)” – that is, they will eventually develop symptoms ‒ may unknowingly spread the disease to others before they realize that they are ill. The [CDC estimates](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/planning-scenarios.html) that as many as 40 percent of COVID cases are asymptomatic.

questions.question: Are children at risk of becoming sick with COVID?
questions.answer: Children can become infected and sick with COVID. According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html#Children), fewer children get sick than adults and most display mild symptoms or are [asymptomatic](/glossary#asymptomatic). However, children with underlying medical conditions or infants (less than 1 year old) may be at increased risk for severe illness. There have also been cases of a rare disease called [multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C)](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/children/mis-c.html), which has been linked to COVID.

questions.question: How long are you contagious with COVID?
questions.answer: According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/end-home-isolation.html), a person with COVID is most likely no longer contagious when (1) at least 10 days have passed since symptom onset; (2) at least 24 hours have passed fever-free without the use of fever-reducing medications; and (3) other symptoms have improved. If you never develop symptoms, you can still be contagious for 10 days after your first positive test. However, [experts](https://www.health.harvard.edu/diseases-and-conditions/if-youve-been-exposed-to-the-coronavirus#:~:text=Most%20people%20with%20coronavirus%20who,there%20are%20documented%20exceptions.) recommend quarantining for a full 14 days in case symptoms develop. You can ensure that you are no longer contagious with COVID after 10 days by receiving two [PCR](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#pcr-test) or [antigen](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#antigen-test) tests 24 hours apart that are both negative for the virus.

questions.question: Can you get COVID twice?
questions.answer: While [antibodies](/glossary#antibodies) may offer some protection against the virus and documented cases of reinfection are rare, there is no evidence to suggest that people are immune to COVID after their first infection. The current understanding of reinfection is limited due to the novelty of the virus, but ongoing studies will provide more insight into how frequently reinfection occurs and how long immunity from COVID may last after your first infection. Even if you’ve already had COVID or have antibodies, the [CDC recommends](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/reinfection.html#:~:text=Cases%20of%20reinfection%20with%20COVID,some%20reinfections%20are%20expected.) taking the same precautions against the virus, including [mask wearing](/glossary#face-mask) and [social distancing](/glossary#social-distancing).

questions.question: What are the long-term effects of COVID?
questions.answer: While some people recover quickly from COVID, others suffer debilitating, long-term symptoms, according to the [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/coronavirus/in-depth/coronavirus-long-term-effects/art-20490351). In Italy, which was one of the first countries to be hit hard by the disease, many survivors are still experiencing health problems after having COVID. In one [study](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2768351), more than 87 percent of individuals experienced one or more symptoms (most commonly fatigue and difficulty breathing) after recovery from COVID. Meanwhile, a German [study](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamacardiology/fullarticle/2768916) found that 78 of 100 recovered COVID patients continued to experience heart abnormalities months after [infection](/glossary#infection).

questions.question: What is counted as a COVID death?
questions.answer:
The [WHO](https://www.who.int/classifications/icd/Guidelines_Cause_of_Death_COVID-19.pdf?ua=1) states that a COVID death can be “a death resulting from a clinically compatible illness, in a probable or confirmed COVID-19 case, unless there is a clear alternative cause of death that cannot be related to COVID disease (e.g. trauma). There should be no period of complete recovery from COVID-19 between illness and death.” (The CDC’s  offers further [guidance](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/covid19/coding-and-reporting.htm) on reporting and coding deaths due to COVID.)

Tracking the number of COVID deaths is difficult, and some suggest that the number is underreported. One issue is that individuals infected with the [virus](/glossary#virus) may be sick for many days, or even weeks, before death, so the increase in deaths resulting from a [wave](/glossary#wave) of [infections](/glossary#infection) may lag significantly in time. In some cases people may die indirectly from COVID, because hospitals were overcrowded with COVID patients and care was late or unavailable. To track the number of COVID deaths, researchers rely on something called “excess mortality” — the number of deaths from all causes during a crisis that are above the historical average during non-crisis times. For information on excess mortality, see the CDC’s report, [Excess Deaths Associated with COVID-19](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/vsrr/covid19/excess_deaths.htm).

questions.question: Why is infection rate important?
questions.answer:
Infection rate, also known as R(t) or “R-effective,” is important because it estimates how fast COVID is spreading right now.

To give an example, if the R(t) is 3, it indicates that one infected person will most likely infect three other people, and those three people will each go on to infect three more people. We as a community can change it by modifying community behavior (whether there are large gatherings) and intervention practices (whether people wear masks and maintain social distancing).

![infection rate diagram shows how many people one person would go on to infect if RT is 3.](/images_cms/infection-rate-diagram.png "COVID spread if infection rate is 3")

questions.question: What is R-naught (R₀) and how is it different from R(t)?
questions.answer: R-naught (R₀), represents the natural ability of a virus to spread in an unprotected population where no special precautions are being taken. [R(t)](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#rt), in contrast, takes into account public health measures or the development of a [vaccine](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#vaccine). This makes R(t) —the actual or “effective” of the virus under current conditions — a more accurate reflection of the number of people that a single infected person is expected to infect in a specific area at a specific time. It is also more relevant than R₀ in directing public policy and informing private behavior. The value of R(t) can change over time, depending on such factors as how many people are staying home or wearing masks. At Covid Act Now, we look at R(t), or [infection rate](https://covidactnow.org/covid-risk-levels-metrics#infection-rate), because it represents more closely what is happening right now and is calculated based on actual case data.

questions.question: Why is testing important?
questions.answer: Diagnostic testing allows health officials to identify and isolate infected individuals and begin [contact tracing](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#contact-tracing) to [quarantine](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#quarantine) people who were exposed. It also allows public health officials to collect the data and information necessary to know when it is safe to resume ordinary activities or when [nonpharmaceutical interventions](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#npi) like [masks](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#face-mask) are critical. Leaders of the [American Heart Association](https://www.heart.org/en/news/2020/04/02/covid-19-science-why-testing-is-so-important), the [American Medical Association](https://www.ama-assn.org/delivering-care/public-health/why-cdc-was-right-revise-coronavirus-testing-guidelines) and the [National Institute on Aging](https://www.nia.nih.gov/news/why-covid-19-testing-key-getting-back-normal), among other organizations, have all urged for an expansion of testing.

questions.question: What does positive test rate tell us?
questions.answer:
Positive test rate, also known as test positivity, is a good indicator of how widespread testing is in a given area. If a state or county has a *high* positive test rate, it is a sign of insufficient testing in that area. If a state or county has a *low* positive test rate, it is a sign that we are testing more than only the sickest people. Testing a larger number of at-risk populations (essential workers, people notified via contact tracing , etc.) is key to catching unknown infections before they can lead to an outbreak.

Let’s look at the pictures below. **There are two positive COVID tests in each of these scenarios, but the positive test rate differs drastically due to the percentage of the population that is being tested.** The closer we get to testing everyone, the less likely we are to miss positive cases.

![key for images](/images_cms/test-positivity-calculate-key.jpg "key for images")

![scenario of insufficient testing with positive test rate of 20 percent, where only 10 percent of the population is tested. ](/images_cms/test-positivity-calculate-high.jpg "Insufficient testing scenario")

In the first scenario, two out of 10 people test positive for COVID, so the positive test rate is 20 percent. The remaining 90 percent of the population remain untested.

![scenario of bare minimum testing with positive test rate of 10 percent, where only 20 percent of the population is tested. ](/images_cms/test-positivity-calculate-medium.jpg "Scenario of bare minimum testing")

In the second scenario, two out of 20 people test positive for COVID, so the positive test rate is 10 percent. The remaining 80 percent of the population remain untested.

![scenario of sufficient testing with positive test rate of 2 percent, where 100 percent of the population is tested. ](/images_cms/test-positivity-calculate-low.jpg "Scenario with sufficient testing")

In the last scenario, two out of 100 people test positive for COVID, so the test positivity is 2 percent. The entire population is tested.

questions.question: Why is ICU capacity used important?
questions.answer: The ICU is the part of a hospital for people who are the sickest. Each ICU bed is staffed by specially trained personnel and supported with special equipment, such as ventilators. They are needed to treat not only COVID patients, but also other patients, such as people who have had a heart attack or suffered a life-threatening injury.

questions.question: Why is % vaccinated important?
questions.answer: The progress of the vaccine roll-out is a key metric for understanding when a return to normal might be possible. We don’t yet know what level of vaccination will be sufficient, so at this stage in the process (March 2021) we are focusing on distribution as the key metric. We will continue to work with our academic and government partners to evaluate the scientific evidence and will update our metric when appropriate.

questions.question: Is it safe to reopen schools?
questions.answer:
A growing body of evidence collected during the fall suggests that schools can reopen, and stay open, while achieving low or near zero in-school COVID transmission to both children and adults. Crucially, low or near zero in-school transmission can be maintained even when transmission within the local community is high, if the school implements a strict infection control strategy.

For instance, schools can focus on developing effective protocols for [testing](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#testing), [contract tracing](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#contact-tracing), vaccination, and providing [masks](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#face-mask) and other [protective equipment](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#ppe). Still, some schools may face greater limitations. They may have a greater density of students and employees in buildings, poorer ventilation and less opportunity for outdoor learning. Covid Act Now provides decision makers with [data](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#data) to assess risk and consider the ability of the school and school district to keep students and teachers safe. [Learn more](https://covidactnow.org/covid-explained/school-guidance).

questions.question: How do you travel safely?
questions.answer:
For the time being, it is still safest not to travel, especially for people who have not yet received the vaccine. If you are fully vaccinated, the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated-guidance.html#anchor_1617376530945) now states that you can travel domestically with low risk to yourself. But, you should still take precautions including wearing a mask and social distancing.

More generally, the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/faqs.html) recommends that you avoid non essential travel by plane, as it could require you to sit close to others for hours. If you must travel, look at the data on [our site](https://covidactnow.org/) to compare the state and county risk levels where you will be. If you plan to fly, take time to research and assess the measures different airlines are taking to reduce risky behaviors and comply with local laws to contain the spread of COVID.

questions.question: How soon after a possible exposure to COVID should you get tested?
questions.answer: It’s important to get tested for COVID after any potential [exposure](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#exposed) to the [virus](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#virus), whether that’s through contact with a [confirmed case](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#confirmed-case) or traveling in close company with strangers. Since COVID has a long [incubation period](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#incubation-period), it may take a few days before [PCR tests](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#pcr-test) detect a sufficient enough amount of the virus to report a positive result, leading to high rates of [false-negatives](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#false-negative) during the first few days after exposure. While it’s always recommended to [quarantine](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#quarantine) for 14 days, [experts recommend](https://medical.mit.edu/covid-19-updates/2020/07/when-should-i-be-tested) being tested five to seven days after a probable exposure for the most accurate test results.

Rapid tests, also known as antigen tests, and PCR tests are the two types of diagnostic tests for COVID. Both tests are performed by collecting nasal or throat swabs, but antigen tests report results in minutes while PCR tests can take up to a week to return results depending on lab capacity. While rapid tests are more convenient and often cheaper, they report significantly higher rates of false negatives of [up to 50 percent](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/which-test-is-best-for-covid-19-2020081020734). PCR tests, on the other hand, report between 2 percent to 37 percent false negatives. PCR tests are most accurate for detecting active infections, while rapid tests are [best used](https://twitter.com/covidactnow/status/1321254254997204992?s=21) to confirm COVID symptoms.
questions.question: Are rapid tests less accurate than PCR tests?
Do masks help stop the spread of COVID?
questions.answer: Yes! [Masks](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#face-mask) that cover your nose and mouth are extremely helpful in reducing the spread of COVID. They help to protect you and those around you, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2020/p0714-americans-to-wear-masks.html) and [WHO](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public/when-and-how-to-use-masks). The virus can spread between people interacting in close proximity, even if no one is exhibiting any [symptoms](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#asymptomatic), and wearing a mask gives you an added layer of protection. While a [growing amount of research](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/science-briefs/fully-vaccinated-people.html) indicates that vaccines may be able to prevent transmission, experts still recommend that [fully vaccinated people](https://covidactnow.org/faq#If-COVID-vaccine-do-I-need-wear-mask-and-social-distance) wear masks in public until more information is available.

questions.question: What kind of masks are the most effective?
questions.answer: Wearing a [mask](/glossary#face-mask) is extremely important to help contain COVID and decreases the risks for both you and those around you. However, not all masks are created equal. [Experts](https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/11/health/cdc-face-mask-guidelines-wellness/index.html) recommend wearing two- or three-ply masks made with a tight weave of 100 percent cotton. Disposable and silk masks are also effective at repelling droplets. More people are wearing two layers of face masks, which some experts say makes common sense. Most important, however, is making sure your mask fits snugly over the bridge of your nose and below your chin. Studies have shown that loose-fitting masks, such as bandanas and gaiters, are the least effective. While N95 masks are the most effective at filtering out particles, they are still considered critical supplies and should be reserved for health care workers and first responders.

questions.question: How do you discuss the pandemic with friends or family members who aren’t taking it seriously?
questions.answer:
It can be challenging to discuss the pandemic with people who think it’s overblown and aren’t taking precautions. You may be tempted to immediately begin reciting the facts and what the data is showing, but sometimes this can put people off. Instead, it’s important to consider how you are presenting those facts. [Research](https://www.mikeyeomans.info/papers/receptiveness.pdf) finds that conversations are more productive when you avoid condescending tones and let the other person know that you are listening. Try these approaches:

* Actively solicit their perspective on the issue, and show that you are listening (e.g., say “I hear you” or “I see what you mean”). When you understand the beliefs of your friends or family members, you can tailor how you communicate with them in a way that resonates with them instead of turning them off. 
* Avoid allowing your emotions to get the best of you. Stay calm and objective, using a friendly tone to share your thoughts. A collected and approachable tone improves the chances of your counterpart listening to the facts and learning from you.

questions.question: What can you do to help end the pandemic and protect yourself from COVID?
questions.answer:
Your actions matter. You can help protect others and slow the spread of the virus by doing a few simple things:

* [Get vaccinated](https://covidactnow.org/faq#how-get-vaccine-for-myself-or-someone) as soon as you can. As of April 19, all adults 16 and older are eligible for the vaccine. 
* Wear a [mask](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#face-mask) unless there is a medical reason not to do so and practice social distancing. If you are fully vaccinated, you should continue to wear a mask and practice social distancing in public spaces. 
* Follow recommended limits on in-person gatherings, especially those that take place indoors. If you are fully vaccinated, you should limit in-person gatherings to include only other fully vaccinated people or one household of low-risk, unvaccinated individuals. 

If infected or exposed, strictly follow the [CDC guidelines](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/quarantine.html) on isolation and [quarantine](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#quarantine).
